qas.question: What organization is the Institute of Russian Language part of?
What can optional acute accents indicate?
What is distinguished from 'lock' only by an accent, in Russian?
What is distinguished from 'this is odd' only by an accent, in Russian?
What is distinguished from 'wothwhile' only by an accent, in Russian?
What organization writes books for Russian learners?
What should be used to teach Russian learners according to the Russian Academy of Sciences?
What do children feel when they are learning Russian?
Where is context mandatory for children and Russian learners?
Where can a Russian learner usually find uncommon words?

context: According to the <b5_0>Institute of Russian Language<b5_0/> of the <a0_0>Russian Academy of Sciences<a0_0/>, an optional acute accent (знак ударения) may, and sometimes should, be used to mark <a1_0><b7_0>stress<b7_0/><a1_0/>. For example, it is used to distinguish between otherwise identical words, especially when context does not make it obvious: замо́к/за́мок (lock/<a2_0>castle<a2_0/>), сто́ящий/стоя́щий (worthwhile/<a4_0>standing<a4_0/>), чудно́/чу́дно (this is odd/<a3_0>this is marvelous<a3_0/>), молоде́ц/мо́лодец (attaboy/fine young man), узна́ю/узнаю́ (I shall learn it/I recognize it), отреза́ть/отре́зать (to be cutting/to have cut); to indicate the proper pronunciation of uncommon words, especially personal and family names (афе́ра, гу́ру, Гарси́я, Оле́ша, Фе́рми), and to show which is the stressed word in a sentence (Ты́ съел печенье?/Ты съе́л печенье?/Ты съел пече́нье? – Was it you who ate the cookie?/Did you eat the cookie?/Was it the cookie that you ate?). Stress marks are mandatory <b8_0>in <b6_0><b9_0>lexical dictionaries<b9_0/><b6_0/> and books<b8_0/> for children or Russian learners.
